snippet.textDisplay:
In case you manage to see this, Gigguk...


I heartily suggest that you slow your release schedule, and pre-determine 4 specific weeks throughout the year where you take a vacation. After all, even those of us who only work 40-hours a week get vacations (well... mostly, kind of), and I'm guessing you put in considerably more than 40 hours each week. I realize that reducing the frequency of your uploads introduces a host of other problems, many of which are financial ones, but, if I may be completely and totally honest, I love your content. I hope to see you making videos -- quality videos, as you've been making -- for another seven years. I hope that you can establish a strong enough brand identity that you could even manage to RETIRE some day, possibly passing the torch to another aspiring artist who will continue your legacy. However, none of that happens if you crash and burn because you're inundated yourself with enough work to crush a mech.


I'm just one rando on the internet, and I don't know all the details of your situation, but I hope that you'll get adequate rest -- if not for yourself, then for us. Please.
snippet.textOriginal:

After all, even those of us who only work 40-hours a week get vacations (well... mostly, kind of), and I'm guessing you put in considerably more than 40 hours each week.  I realize that reducing the frequency of your uploads introduces a host of other problems, many of which are financial ones, but, if I may be completely and totally honest, I love your content.   I hope to see you making videos -- quality videos, as you've been making -- for another seven years.  I hope that you can establish a strong enough brand identity that you could even manage to RETIRE some day, possibly passing the torch to another aspiring artist who will continue your legacy.  However, none of that happens if you crash and burn because you're inundated yourself with enough work to crush a mech.


I'm just one rando on the internet, and I don't know all the details of your situation, but I hope that you'll get adequate rest -- if not for yourself, then for us.  Please.

Gigguk: What if we took this one rape scene from Valvrave and then make a show about that?

snippet.textDisplay: I have to agree. I've been dating my boyfriend (an avid gundam fan) for 9 years. More than enough time to actually catch up on the basic timeline and history. But I hate how 80s anime looks, I hate tropes and I can just ask said boyfriend questions when something comes up so I've ignored the franchise, bought him a few gunpla and called it a day, whereas I've gotten into more accessible shows you can jump into with absolutely minimal background like Godzilla and Macross. I do love giant robots and action, after all. However, I'm not willing to sink 30 hours into something BEFORE I know I like it, and I know starting at the beginning won't hook me. Iron Blooded Orphans is on my to do list, but with so many other anime on there as well, it's not #1 either
snippet.textOriginal: I have to agree. I've been dating my boyfriend (an avid gundam fan) for 9 years. More than enough time to actually catch up on the basic timeline and history. But I hate how 80s anime looks, I hate tropes and I can just ask said boyfriend questions when something comes up so I've ignored the franchise, bought him a few gunpla and called it a day, whereas I've gotten into more accessible shows you can jump into with absolutely minimal background like Godzilla and Macross. I do love giant robots and action, after all. However, I'm not willing to sink 30 hours into something BEFORE I know I like it, and I know starting at the beginning won't hook me. Iron Blooded Orphans is on my to do list, but with so many other anime on there as well, it's not #1 either

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey Gigguk. You're not gonna see this because it's been over a week and there are now... 10,636 comments. Buuuuut... I don't want to watch new Gundam. I don't want to see angsty teens instantly overpowered from episode 1, making the whole anime like like a Musou game. I'm not really all that interested in seeing a war being fought, and that war being made to see pointless by the end of the series. I also don't want to jump into a timeline that oversaturated with TV shows and OVAs, half of which would be extremely difficult to track down.

I want an interstellar mecha anime. Give me aliens with mechs, or at least divergent humans with mechs. I want to see fighting on a variety of worlds, and in giant space battles. And I don't want the mecha to invalidate all other kinds of fighting vehicles. I don't want a beam cannon that can vaporize a whole fleet of battleships in a single shot. Because I mean... why not just put that on the battleships, then? I want a mecha anime where there's a rivalry between mecha pilots and fighter pilots and marines, or whatever. I want a mecha anime that deals with tactics, strategy, and maybe even logistics. And maybe there's no clear good or bad guy (or maybe there is), but at least make it so that the war has consequences depending on who wins. And then start all this in a fresh new universe.

Or you know what, maybe even something Stargate SG-1-styled, where the humans start out with modern or near-future tech and struggle to push back an advanced invader. The map of the Earth is rewritten because many nations simply collapse and have to reform. Then the humans learn from and adapt their technology and eventually take the war back to them. Is that Macross? I dunno, I haven't seen it, but maybe that's Macross. Shit, and why not make the aliens monsters INSIDE of mecha? Like, they're already super-dangerous outside their mechs.
snippet.textOriginal:

I'm not really all that interested in seeing a war being fought, and that war being made to see pointless by the end of the series. I also don't want to jump into a timeline that oversaturated with TV shows and OVAs, half of which would be extremely difficult to track down.

I want an interstellar mecha anime. Give me aliens with mechs, or at least divergent humans with mechs. I want to see fighting on a variety of worlds, and in giant space battles. And I don't want the mecha to invalidate all other kinds of fighting vehicles. I don't want a beam cannon that can vaporize a whole fleet of battleships in a single shot. Because I mean... why not just put that on the battleships, then? I want a mecha anime where there's a rivalry between mecha pilots and fighter pilots and marines, or whatever. I want a mecha anime that deals with tactics, strategy, and maybe even logistics. And maybe there's no clear good or bad guy (or maybe there is), but at least make it so that the war has consequences depending on who wins. And then start all this in a fresh new universe.

Or you know what, maybe even something Stargate SG-1-styled, where the humans start out with modern or near-future tech and struggle to push back an advanced invader. The map of the Earth is rewritten because many nations simply collapse and have to reform. Then the humans learn from and adapt their technology and eventually take the war back to them. Is that Macross? I dunno, I haven't seen it, but maybe that's Macross. Shit, and why not make the aliens monsters INSIDE of mecha? Like, they're already super-dangerous outside their mechs.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the problem is in fact, that the bigest part of all mecha is about war, heroes of war, powerful and great robots, which has been made for controling the world. People in the modern world don't think that humen's science is great and can rule this world. I think this thoughts are in past now. Couse we understand  now: we can't control everithing. We are explorers not conquerors. We don't like stories about heroes of war, cause we understand now, there is no black and white in war. War is a wrong decision for all countries. I think we want to see big robots as an artwork not as a weapon or a giant tractor now. Sorry, my English is bad. I'm russian.

snippet.textDisplay: I think Gundam series has taken a dip, since 00 (which im a big fan of), and Unicorn (which really catches my eye) AND Origins (which I loved), there hasn't been anything after good after. Gundam Build fighters is a disgrace and Iron Blood Orphans could not keep my attention (personally don't like Mikazuki). Until Gundam comes with better story to go with the mech anime, gundam will continue to drop. Now gunpla is a different story, I feel Gunpla is booming compared to the anime.
snippet.textOriginal: I think Gundam series has taken a dip, since 00 (which im a big fan of), and Unicorn (which really catches my eye) AND Origins (which I loved), there hasn't been anything after good after. snippet.textDisplay: I'm gonna get a lot of hate because it's "not a real anime", but the least shit storm of a mecha anime this past decade was probably Voltron: Legendary Defender. Not to say it wasn't a shit storm though. While many character arcs just ended and the story was repetitive during the middle seasons, it pulled off an amazing finale season. I think the best this decade were Code: Geass, Gundam Unicorn, Darling in the Franxx, Neon Genesis Evangelion, and Voltron: Legendary Defender.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm gonna get a lot of hate because it's "not a real anime", but the least shit storm of a mecha anime this past decade was probably Voltron: Legendary Defender. Not to say it wasn't a shit storm though. While many character arcs just ended and the story was repetitive during the middle seasons, it pulled off an amazing finale season. I think the best this decade were Code: Geass, Gundam Unicorn, Darling in the Franxx, Neon Genesis Evangelion, and Voltron: Legendary Defender.

snippet.textDisplay: Honestly, if Trigger got ahold of a property like Transformers and made the most anime of animes with it, I think giant robots would be cool again. It's SO HARD to fuck up giant robots that it pains me to see the stat the genre is in. Transformers and Power Rangers and Ultraman are always rebooting with little ties to the previous series that it would be perfect to foster new fans and introduce them to the wider genre. They just need to get good writers and some creativity

snippet.textDisplay:
Yea, been sad to see the decline of mecha the past decade. Have to agree with Gigguk about most mecha shows being just ok/meh with not too many standouts. Still there has been some great and fun mecha shows in the 2010's.

Here's my top 5:
1. Gundam Iron-Blooded Orphans (surprised this wasn't more popular)
2. Knights of Sidonia (such an underrated gem just bc of the CG)
3. Broken Blade (RIP manga/any future sequel)
4. Gargantia on the Verdurous Planet (freaking Viz still not bringing over the sequel OVA's)
5. Darling in the FRANXX (still enjoyable train wreck ending and all)
snippet.textOriginal:
Yea, been sad to see the decline of mecha the past decade. Have to agree with Gigguk about most mecha shows being just ok/meh with not too many standouts. Still there has been some great and fun mecha shows in the 2010's.
 
Here's my top 5:
1. Gundam Iron-Blooded Orphans (surprised this wasn't more popular)
2. Knights of Sidonia (such an underrated gem just bc of the CG)
3. Broken Blade (RIP manga/any future sequel)
4. Gargantia on the Verdurous Planet (freaking Viz still not bringing over the sequel OVA's)
5. Darling in the FRANXX (still enjoyable train wreck ending and all)

snippet.textDisplay: What made Gundam 00 great (IMHO) was that it was clearly rooted in a post-9/11 geopolitical world. It dealt with topics that were... topical at the time, such as terrorism and the use of force to stop wars. Despite the problems it had, I believe it to be one of the best AU gundams in the franchise. Iron-Blooded Orphans is a close second, but without the parallels to real world issues at the time, it just feels like a story rather than something that's looking to dissect a complex topic like many Gundam series try to do. Gundam is much like the "of the Dead" movie franchise, where it is at its best when it's making some commentary on some aspect of war or politics. With the tumultuous nature of politics as we go into the new decade, it's only a matter of time before a new Gundam that's not designed strictly as a toy commercial crops up.
snippet.textOriginal: What made Gundam 00 great (IMHO) was that it was clearly rooted in a post-9/11 geopolitical world. It dealt with topics that were... topical at the time, such as terrorism and the use of force to stop wars. Despite the problems it had, I believe it to be one of the best AU gundams in the franchise. Iron-Blooded Orphans is a close second, but without the parallels to real world issues at the time, it just feels like a story rather than something that's looking to dissect a complex topic like many Gundam series try to do. Gundam is much like the "of the Dead" movie franchise, where it is at its best when it's making some commentary on some aspect of war or politics. With the tumultuous nature of politics as we go into the new decade, it's only a matter of time before a new Gundam that's not designed strictly as a toy commercial crops up.

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly, im not big into mecha, but i do enjoy it
e.g. i liked Muv-Luv despite it really....creative...alien design because i thought the mechas are cool


But yeah i admit i never looked into Gundam because i knew it was old (i mean, it started long ago) and i feel like i would miss alot if i would´t rewatch at least half of the older series wich i just can´t afford to. But i´d definitly look into it if i knew that Gundam X or Y would be a good starting point without actually missing 80% of the content


I mean i started playing ME3 without playing 1 and 2...later i played 1 and 2 retuned to 3 and hell i missed alot with starting with the last entry


Point is if i knew the exact titel i´d watch it...however i can´t really look into it myself since i don´t know ANYTHING about Gundum besides i migth encounter a Mech or 2
snippet.textOriginal:
Honestly, im not big into mecha, but i do enjoy it

But yeah i admit i never looked into Gundam because i knew it was old (i mean, it started long ago) and i feel like i would miss alot if i would´t rewatch at least half of the older series wich i just can´t afford to. But i´d definitly look into it if i knew that Gundam X or Y would be a good starting point without actually missing 80% of the content


I mean i started playing ME3 without playing 1 and 2...later i played 1 and 2  retuned to 3 and hell i missed alot with starting with the last entry


Point is if i knew the exact titel i´d watch it...however i can´t really look into it myself since i don´t know ANYTHING about Gundum besides i migth encounter a Mech or 2
